instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - fan spin - no vcore
threads.message:
Hi all,

I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had no power missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

Traced that back to a corroded <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>.

Now it spins and draws 0.14 amps. I have no vcore and cpu is cold.

On <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> i have all the inputs around 0.7v but <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0.2v (i think this should be 3.3v?)

I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> just in case but no luck.

On <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> i have SMC DELAYED, 3v42 and <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL>.

But all sys is 0.2v and <SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL> are both 0v

any ideas?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - fan spin - no vcore
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> should be present that is why there is no Vcore.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is being pulled down so first measure resistance to GND on this line. Then check if all rails are actually present

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - fan spin - no vcore
threads.message: Thanks Duke - <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> had no 5v input - ran a wire and we're on!
